content.question: Which of the following statements best explains the trend in the molar solubility of <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in various concentrations of <math alttext="N a F, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>F</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> shown in the graph above?

choices.label: Higher concentrations of <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> allow less <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to dissolve before the solution becomes saturated.

Higher concentrations of <math alttext="N a with a positive 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> lead to more favorable attractions between <math alttext="N a with a positive 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions and <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions, thus less <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves.

Higher concentrations of <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> produce more <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> through hydrolysis, causing <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext><mo>(</mo><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to precipitate, thus more <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves.

Higher concentrations of <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> cause the formation of the <math alttext="C a F 4 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> complex ion, which allows more <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to dissolve.

content.answer: Higher concentrations of <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> allow less <math alttext="C a F 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to dissolve before the solution becomes saturated.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
